author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: TikTok, the Fastest Way on Earth to Become a Food Star
description: The app offers explosive growth for content creators. Gen Z cooks are taking advantage.
content: Eitan Bernath, a 19-year-old TikTok star with more than 1.6 million followers, began posting cooking content to the platform in 2019. Like many Generation Z TikTok chefs, he taught himself to cook by watching YouTube and the Food Network. He would share the things he made to Instagram, but never gained much traction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Who Is Roman Protasevich, the Captive Journalist in Belarus?
description: Mr. Protasevich, 26, is an exiled dissident whose reach drew an authoritarian ruler into a gambit that outraged Western governments.
content: It has all of the elements of a Jason Bourne plot: A commercial flight carrying a dissident journalist is intercepted by a MiG-29 fighter jet under orders from the strongman president of Belarus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Day 6: Meditate On the Go!
description: Try this simple five-finger breathing exercise you can do anywhere. (I use this in the dentist chair.) Hold one hand in front of you, fingers spread. Now, slowly trace the outside of your hand with the index finger on your other hand, breathing in when you trace up a finger, and out when you trace down. Move up and down all five fingers. When you’ve traced your whole hand, reverse direction and do it again. Here’s a video animation to help.
content: Try this simple five-finger breathing exercise you can do anywhere. (I use this in the dentist chair.) Hold one hand in front of you, fingers spread. Now, slowly trace the outside of your hand with the index finger on your other hand, breathing in when you trace up a finger, and out when you trace down. Move up and down all five fingers. When you’ve traced your whole hand, reverse direction and do it again. Here’s a video animation to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Florida, in a First, Will Fine Social Media Companies That Bar Candidates
description: The new law is a direct response to Facebook’s and Twitter’s suspensions of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — Florida on Monday became the first state to regulate how companies like Facebook, YouTube and Twitter moderate speech online, by imposing fines on social media companies that permanently bar political candidates in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Kate Kelly
title: Flight paths over Belarus should be assessed, the transportation secretary says.
description: The comments from Pete Buttigieg came after the authoritarian leader of Belarus dispatched a fighter jet on Sunday to intercept a Ryanair plane.
content: The transportation secretary said Monday that the safety of flights operated by U.S. airlines over Belarus should be reviewed after the Eastern European country forced a commercial flight to land in order to seize a dissident on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Happy Birthday, Bob Dylan, Our Most Underappreciated Comic
description: As he turns 80, don’t be fooled by his serious music. From the start, his work has been filled with a cockeyed humor that can range from corny jokes to dark wit.
content: At the end of “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the Coen brothers movie set in the Greenwich Village music scene of 1961, the title character, a gifted but struggling folk singer on the verge of giving up, leaves the stage of the fabled Gaslight Café as a newcomer fills his spot. What’s clear after the first note is that it’s Bob Dylan at the start of one of the greatest careers in pop music
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: As Israel’s Dependence on U.S. Shrinks, So Does U.S. Leverage
description: Israel has quietly sought, and perhaps achieved, a large measure of autonomy from its half-century of reliance on the United States.
content: Israel, a small country surrounded by adversaries and locked in conflict with the Palestinians, depends absolutely on American diplomatic and military support. By giving it, the United States safeguards Israel and wields significant leverage over its actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Delhi looks at loosening rules, not long after a crisis point.
content: Six weeks after it was rocked by a devastating coronavirus surge, the region is considering relaxing its Covid-19 restrictions. Officials are pledging to ramp up vaccinations to protect New Delhi’s more than 20 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Wine Tours Ramp Up on Long Island
description: New York Wine Events has added more private tours of wineries in the North Fork. There are trips planned to the Hudson Valley, too.
content: New York Wine Events, which conducts day trips to the wine country of Long Island and Hudson Valley, has expanded its schedule this year, a smart move considering that people who are resuming travel as pandemic restrictions ease are doing so closer to home. Custom trips for groups of two or more are now available daily through the end of the year. Round trip transportation can be arranged from a pickup point in any of the city’s boroughs, plus Long Island for North Fork wineries or Westchester and Rockland Counties for the Hudson Valley. There will be a sommelier present as the group visits two wineries and samples four to five wines at each stop. A visit to a farm stand is included. Participants must be at least 21 years old and tours have to be booked at least 48 hours in advance. The tours go rain or shine, follow any pandemic protocols and start at $159 per person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israeli Police Round Up More Than 1,550 Suspects in Mob Violence
description: At least 70 percent of those arrested are Arab citizens of Israel. Three Israeli Jews are charged with the attempted murder of an Arab driver.
content: JERUSALEM — More than 1,550 people have been arrested over the past two weeks, the Israeli police said on Monday, on suspicion of involvement in the recent outbreak of mob violence between Arabs and Jews that convulsed cities across Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: How Online Sleuths Pantsed Putin
description: Bellingcat’s founder, Eliot Higgins, on the ethics of open source investigations and what separates his organization from online vigilantes.
content: It turns out you can use a prank call to expose suspected poisoners, mole patterns to identify a violent demonstrator at a white nationalist rally and online videos to reveal a weapons-smuggling operation to Syrian rebels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan and Noor Qasim
title: John Updike on Parenting, Agatha Christie in the Gossip Pages: First Mentions of Famous Authors in The Times
description: Have you ever wondered when your favorite writers first appeared in the pages of the paper? It might be earlier than you think.
content: It felt only fitting, during the Book Review’s 125th anniversary, to delve into the archives and showcase the best, funniest, most surprising first mentions we could find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: To Find New York’s Best Jerk, Follow the Smoke
description: With locations in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx, Forever Jerk sets a standard for chicken and pork smoked Jamaican-style.
content: When Forever Jerk’s operation in Brooklyn is going full throttle, the smoke is visible from at least a quarter-mile away. I saw it for the first time as I was driving down Pennsylvania Avenue toward the Starrett City housing complex, and I thought somebody had thrown a couple of couches out on the street and set them both on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: ‘Delayed Prescribing’ May Help Cut Down on Antibiotic Use
description: Most respiratory illnesses don’t require antibiotics, which can have harmful side effects.
content: Should you take antibiotics for a simple respiratory infection?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A State-Sponsored Skyjacking Can’t Go Unanswered
description: Mr. Lukashenko has gone too far, and the response should be convincing and swift.
content: Aleksandr Lukashenko, the president of Belarus, has gone too far. Hijacking a commercial airliner to kidnap an opposition journalist is simply too dangerous a violation of international norms for the United States, the European Union and other responsible states to let pass without serious consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: New Variant Posing Threat, as Global Vaccine Drive Falters
description: The coronavirus variant first seen in India is rapidly outpacing all others in Britain, a problem for the U.K. and a potential new burden on poorer nations.
content: LONDON — A new and potentially more contagious variant of the coronavirus has begun to outpace other versions of the virus in Britain, putting pressure on the government to shorten people’s wait for second doses of vaccines and illustrating the risks of a faltering global immunization drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The Cicadas Are Here. For the Chef Bun Lai, They’re on the Menu.
description: Several years after he was ridiculed for serving the insects at his family’s sushi restaurant, the chef sees another opportunity to change American minds about consuming cicadas.
content: WOODBRIDGE, CONN. — For Bun Lai, cicadas are mesmerizing to eat, their sweet, bitter flavor reminiscent of walnuts, chestnuts and adzuki beans, and their gently crunchy exterior giving way to creaminess, like a soft shell crab.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Belarus Forces Plane to Land, Seizing Activist
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 24, 2021.
content: “Not a single person who flies over Belarus can be sure of his safety.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Simone Biles Dials Up the Difficulty, ‘Because I Can’
description: The Olympic gold medalist’s new vault is so dangerous that gymnastics, for now, limits the scoring rewards for trying it. Biles says that’s unfair.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Simone Biles, the most decorated gymnast in history, is renowned for performing moves so difficult, and so distinctive, that several have been named after her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Pratt and Rick Rojas
title: Giant Confederate Monument Will Remain at Revamped Stone Mountain
description: Officials at the Georgia park voted to move flags and create exhibits to put the Civil War into fuller context. But the likeness of three Confederate leaders carved into stone isn’t going anywhere.
content: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga. — The Confederate flags that have long flapped at the base of Stone Mountain, placed there by the United Daughters of the Confederacy, will be moved to a less prominent area, joining other relics of the Civil War. New exhibits will offer a fuller and more complicated description of the park’s history, attempting to reach beyond the war it memorializes to the role the Ku Klux Klan and resistance to desegregation played in its creation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: European leaders back efforts to strengthen the W.H.O.
description: Leaders of France and Germany voiced support on Monday for making the World Health Organization more independent and building up its ability to respond to global health crises.
content: Leaders of France and Germany voiced support on Monday for making the World Health Organization more independent and building up its ability to respond to global health crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Anti-Zionism Isn’t Anti-Semitism? Someone Didn’t Get the Memo.
description: An omen for Jews on America’s streets.
content: In recent years it has become an article of faith on the progressive left that anti-Zionism is not anti-Semitism and that it’s slander to assume that someone who hates Israel also hates Jews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: An apparent plane hijacking by Belarus.
content: The brutal and erratic leader of Belarus, Aleksandr Lukashenko, forced a Ryanair flight to land in the country’s capital on Sunday to arrest a prominent Belarusian opposition journalist, prompting international outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden and the Fed say the economic recovery is on the right track, but critics have doubts.
description: McDonald’s, Chipotle and Amazon are all raising pay as companies try to fill jobs faster than they can find workers. Airplane tickets and hotel rooms are becoming more expensive as demand rebounds thanks to newly widespread vaccinations. Supply shortages are making it tougher to buy a house or a new car.
content: McDonald’s, Chipotle and Amazon are all raising pay as companies try to fill jobs faster than they can find workers. Airplane tickets and hotel rooms are becoming more expensive as demand rebounds thanks to newly widespread vaccinations. Supply shortages are making it tougher to buy a house or a new car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Mae Martin Embraces Ambiguity in ‘Feel Good,’ and in Life
description: In an interview, the creator and star of the Netflix comedy discusses the hazy line between fact and fiction, the value of uncertainty and the joy of finally getting to be a leading man.
content: Mae Martin didn’t set out to confront a throng of personal demons with the semi-autobiographical tragicomic Netflix series “Feel Good.” That’s just how it played out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Desiree Rios
title: The pandemic has taken a devastating toll on undocumented women in New York.
description: The nearly half a million undocumented immigrants who live in New York City were devastated by the pandemic, stricken by the virus and the economic fallout it caused and ineligible for stimulus checks and the unemployment benefits that kept many New Yorkers afloat.
content: The nearly half a million undocumented immigrants who live in New York City were devastated by the pandemic, stricken by the virus and the economic fallout it caused and ineligible for stimulus checks and the unemployment benefits that kept many New Yorkers afloat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauntel Lowe
title: W.N.B.A. Suspends Coach for Body-Shaming Liz Cambage
description: Cambage, the Las Vegas Aces center, said Connecticut Sun Coach Curt Miller had made disrespectful comments about her weight during a game on Sunday.
content: The W.N.B.A. suspended and fined Curt Miller, the head coach of the Connecticut Sun, after he was called out by Las Vegas Aces center Liz Cambage for body-shaming her during a game on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Kate Taylor
title: States and cities across the U.S. debate the future of online learning.
description: Some school systems may follow New York City’s lead and stop offering remote instruction in the fall, while others retain the option for at least some families.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic ebbs in the United States and vaccines become available for teenagers, school systems are facing the difficult choice of whether to continue offering a remote learning option in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: N.J.’s governor abandons rules requiring masks indoors for vaccinated people starting Friday.
description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy’s decision to permit vaccinated residents to doff masks comes a week after he stressed that they were still needed.
content: What a difference a week makes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Aung San Suu Kyi Makes First Court Appearance Since Coup
description: Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, 75, faces a raft of charges after being detained by Myanmar’s military. If found guilty, she could be imprisoned for life.
content: For the first time since Myanmar’s military locked her up in a pre-dawn raid as part of its coup on Feb. 1, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmar’s ousted civilian government, was seen in person on Monday when she sat briefly at a court hearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: An Alternate Reality for the WarnerMedia Deal
description: What if Time Warner had gotten a fateful phone call earlier in 2016?
content: After its $100 billion deal to buy Time Warner, and spending millions more to fight a Justice Department lawsuit that delayed the deal, AT&T wants a do-over. The Times has the definitive account of the negotiations that led to the phone giant’s reversal — code names, emoji-speckled emails, artisanal doughnuts, a gun-toting Steve McQueen and a cramped Greenwich Village townhouse all play a part — culminating in the announcement last week that it would spin off WarnerMedia, as the former Time Warner is now known, to merge with the reality TV giant Discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Klobuchar to Propose Ban on Prechecked Boxes in Political Donations
description: Senator Amy Klobuchar is pressing for legislation after a Times investigation showed that the use of prechecked boxes for recurring donations by former President Donald Trump’s campaign led to a surge of refunds.
content: The chair of the Senate Rules Committee, Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, is set to introduce legislation on Monday to ban political campaigns from guiding online donors into recurring donations by default, a practice that has drawn criticism for luring supporters into making unintended gifts that sometimes total in the thousands of dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Quoctrung Bui
title: Small Businesses Have Surged in Black Communities. Was It the Stimulus?
description: New research finds a big rise in new businesses despite the pandemic, particularly in predominantly Black neighborhoods.
content: Over the last year, multiple stimulus measures from the federal government have helped families buy groceries, pay rent and build a financial cushion. This aid might have also helped start a new era of entrepreneurship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: Long After Trump’s Loss, a Push to Inspect Ballots Persists
description: Efforts to review 2020 ballots in Georgia and Arizona reflect the staying power of Donald Trump’s falsehoods, and Democrats fear that the findings could be twisted by Republicans.
content: Georgia has already counted its 2020 presidential vote three times, with the same result: President Biden defeated Donald J. Trump narrowly yet decisively. But now portions of the vote will be inspected for a fourth time, after a judge ruled late last week that a group of voters must be allowed to view copies of all 147,000 absentee ballots cast in the state’s largest county.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Richard Nonas, Who Explored Art and the Space It Inhabits, Dies at 85
description: A part of the early-1970s art scene in SoHo and TriBeCa, he created Post-Minimalist sculptures out of steel, stone and wood.
content: Richard Nonas, a Post-Minimalist sculptor who was influenced by his field work in anthropology to conceive works from found materials that explored how art and the space it occupies affect each other, died on May 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark C. O'Flaherty
title: The Secret Psychology of Sneaker Colors
description: You think they randomly choose those glaring shades of Nike, Adidas and New Balance? Think again.
content: Aqua blue, acid lime and grape purple. Electric orange interspersed with neon pink. Gray suede and cheetah print mixed with white and gold. These are not descriptions of a minimalist’s worst nightmare, but rather new color combinations from Adidas, Reebok and New Balance. And they are jarring by design.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City Mayor’s Race Intensifies
description: The temperature on the campaign trail is rising as the primary race enters its final month.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Thieves Steal Artifacts Worth $1.4 Million From English Castle
description: The treasures, including rosary beads carried by Mary, Queen of Scots, at her execution in 1587, were stolen from a display cabinet at Arundel Castle.
content: LONDON — The thieves broke into an imposing castle in the English countryside and took a rare bounty: rosary beads that once belonged to Mary, Queen of Scots, along with other gold and silver artifacts that the authorities said were worth over $1.4 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Basma Ghalayini
title: A Gazan’s View on Hamas: It’s Not Complicated
description: The right to self-defense against Israel’s continued aggression belongs to all Palestinians.
content: When I was 9 years old, I was shot by the Israel Defense Forces. Most people I grew up with in Gaza have a story like this: a near miss, a face-to-face confrontation with a fatal bombing, a massacre. Mine is nothing special.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘F9’ could be the blockbuster Hollywood needs to kick-start moviegoing.
description: The latest installment in the “Fast and Furious” franchise arrived in theaters over the weekend in eight international markets and sold an estimated $162 million in tickets.
content: LOS ANGELES — In February 2020, Universal Pictures used the Super Bowl to light a marketing match under “F9,” the latest installment in the “Fast and Furious” franchise. With any luck, the studio hoped, the movie would roar into theaters a few months later and take in more than $1 billion worldwide, just as a predecessor, “The Fate of the Furious,” did in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: How a 17-Year-Old’s Birthday Party Became the Biggest Thing on the Internet
description: After Adrian Lopez’s birthday ‘kickback’ went viral on TikTok, thousands of teenagers showed up for the party of the year.
content: A week ago, Adrian Lopez, 17, was just an average high school student in Eastvale, Calif. But after a digital flyer he made inviting friends to Huntington Beach for his birthday went viral — to the point of attracting thousands of strangers to the beach and to an event space in Los Angeles — he’s become a household name on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Extends Agreement With Nuclear Agency, Averting Crisis
description: Tehran agreed to give the International Atomic Energy Agency continued access to cameras at its nuclear sites while it negotiates with the United States over the ruptured 2015 deal.
content: WASHINGTON — Iran agreed on Monday to a one-month extension of an agreement with international inspectors that would allow them to continue monitoring the country’s nuclear program, avoiding a major setback in the continuing negotiations with Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney
title: Belarus grows more isolated as countries weigh punishment for the Ryanair flight force-down.
description: As world condemnation grew, the Ryanair chief accused the Belarusian government of staging a “state-sponsored hijacking.”
content: A day after it brazenly forced down a commercial airline so it could seize a dissident journalist traveling on board, Belarus found itself increasingly isolated on Monday, as other countries considered measures that would effectively make Belarusian airspace off limits to airlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: When It’s OK to Be a Guinea Pig
description: It can be fun to try out new products, but only if we know what we’re signing up for.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iman Stevenson
title: One of Roxane Gay’s Go-To Recipes
description: A slight spin on Melissa Clark’s chicken Milanese has become a mainstay in the author’s kitchen.
content: “I’ve gone full L.A.,” Roxane Gay recently told T, by which she meant she’s gotten into juices and cleanses and “going to the farmers’ market and getting super-fresh produce.” The 46-year-old media multihyphenate — she’s an author, a columnist, a film and TV writer and a podcaster — has lived “full-ish time” in Los Angeles for about three years now. She does, however, still make it to New York every two months or so, traveling with her wife, Debbie Millman, who is a designer, branding consultant, educator, writer and podcaster (the pair met when Gay was a guest on Millman’s podcast, “Design Matters,” and eloped last year), and their new puppy, Maximus Toretto Blueberry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Black History of Barbecue
description: The food historian Adrian Miller’s new book, “Black Smoke,” chronicles a rich culinary contribution.
content: “I want African-American barbecuers properly acknowledged, celebrated for their contributions and sharing in the barbecue prosperity,” writes the food historian Adrian Miller in his new book, “Black Smoke.” Mr. Miller is fed up with the general lack of recognition given to the Black barbecuing community by the media, in cookbooks and on the barbecue event circuit, which he also criticizes for racism. He details the history of barbecue back to its Indigenous roots in pre-Columbian days, and recounts how it became part of the culture of enslaved Africans. It was entrenched in Black community life, but was taken over by white cooks starting in the late 19th century, he writes. Part of this change was because of urbanization. Instead of pit-roasted whole hogs, smaller cuts of meat like ribs and brisket were used because they were easier to handle in restaurants, and chefs got involved. Now the recognition is improving, he says, but there is work to be done. The book is seasoned with profiles of Black barbecue notables and a smattering of recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Richard Webner
title: A Serene Shore Resort, Except for the SpaceX ‘Ball of Fire’
description: For years, those in a rural Texas village cherished living among nature and wildlife. Elon Musk’s SpaceX has brought new fears and the promise of an economic boost to one of America’s poorest corners.
content: BOCA CHICA, Texas — The text arrived late at night: For your own safety, leave home by morning, it read. Nancy and James Crawford, no longer surprised but still unsettled, raced away in their S.U.V. after sunrise, occasionally twisting their necks to catch a glimpse of the space rocket towering behind them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 24, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 24, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Scrounging for Hits, Hollywood Goes Back to the Video Game Well
description: After decades of game-to-film flops, a new effort, led by Sony, aims to adapt big PlayStation and Xbox franchises for movies and TV.
content: LOS ANGELES — For 28 years, ever since “Super Mario Bros.” arrived in cinemas with the tagline “This Ain’t No Game,” Hollywood has been trying and mostly failing — epically, famously — to turn hit video games into hit movies. For every “Lara Croft: Tomb Raider” (2001), which turned Angelina Jolie into an A-list action star, there has been a nonsensical “Max Payne” (2008), an abominable “Prince of Persia” (2010) and a wince-inducing “Warcraft” (2016).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: She Was Supposed to Become Prime Minister but Was Locked Out of Parliament
description: A constitutional crisis deepened in the Pacific Island nation of Samoa, which now has two competing governments and two claimants to the prime ministership.
content: Fiame Naomi Mata’afa walked toward Samoa’s beehive-shaped Parliament House on Monday morning intending to be sworn in as the first female prime minister in the Pacific Island nation’s 56-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Crumbling of the N.R.A.
description: Could an investigation into financial misconduct be the undoing of America’s most powerful gun rights group?
content: For the last three decades, the National Rifle Association — America’s most powerful gun rights group — has been led by Wayne LaPierre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: At a Small Maine School, Cursive Endures and Wins National Awards
description: Although cursive handwriting “is a dying field,” as one teacher said, it has made a comeback in some schools, including one in Maine where two students won awards this month.
content: For years, screens have replaced notebooks, keyboards have subbed in for pens and digital life has revolved around the printed word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Schur and Todd May
title: Mike Schur and Todd May: What We Believe About Freedom
description: We have a moral obligation to others. Refusing to recognize that endangers all of us.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we believe? You can read more essays by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Kevin Spacey Cast in Italian Film After Being Sidelined in the U.S.
description: He will play a detective in the movie, directed by Franco Nero, in what is believed to be his first film since sexual assault allegations started surfacing in 2017.
content: Kevin Spacey has been cast in a film in what is believed to be the first time since accusations of sexual assault against the actor started surfacing more than three years ago, prompting several court cases and unraveling his onscreen career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Military in Mali Detains Country’s Top Officials
description: The action occurred shortly after two military officers lost their positions in a government reshuffle, sources said,
content: BAMAKO, Mali — Military officers in Mali detained the president, prime minister and defense minister of the interim government on Monday, according to diplomatic and government sources, just nine months after a military coup ousted the previous president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: N.Y.C. Will Eliminate Remote Learning for Next School Year
description: All students and staff members will be back in school buildings full time come September, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday.
content: New York City will no longer have a remote schooling option come fall, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday, a major step toward fully reopening the nation’s largest school system and a crucial marker in the city’s economic recovery after more than a year of disruptions caused by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: These N.B.A. Playoffs Burst 2020’s Bubble
description: The confined, roiled 2020 N.B.A. playoffs reflected their times. So, too, do this year’s celebratory games.
content: Last August, as the N.B.A. began its 2020 postseason in the confined bubble of Walt Disney World in Florida, the coronavirus pandemic raged, a vaccine was nothing but a dream and the battle for racial justice stood firmly at the forefront of every game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Clark
title: ‘No One’s Ever Talked to Me About This Before’
description: Social media creators are helping women and people of color identify possible symptoms of A.D.H.D., a disorder most often diagnosed in white boys.
content: “When I was a kid, I had the sense things were more difficult for me,” Tiffany Bui recalled. It was hard for her to focus in school, and she was often forgetful. Throughout her life, she said, members of her family criticized these traits as faults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: After Tragedy, an Indianapolis Theater Stages a Comeback
description: Bryan Fonseca, the founder of a notable company, died of complications from Covid-19. But at the theater named for him, the show goes on.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — On a breezy, 80-degree evening, the sun still in the sky, the actor Chandra Lynch walked to the center of the Fonseca Theater Company’s outdoor stage-in-the-round. At her back was a semicircle of oversized blocks, each with printed words that together formed the sentence “Blackness iz not a monolith.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Oslo’ and Specials Honoring George Floyd
description: A film adaptation of J.T. Rogers’s Tony-winning play airs on HBO. And several specials recognize the anniversary of George Floyd’s murder.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 24-30. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Pearls of Wisdom in This Virtual Class
description: Patrick McMurray, a champion shucker, will lead an hourlong course in oyster shucking next month.
content: Oyster expertise in an hour, in a virtual class, is promised by Food Island Partnership, the organization that promotes shellfish from Prince Edward Island, Canada. Patrick McMurray, a champion shucker, will guide the audience in a free event that covers buying and storing oysters, shucking them (with oysters and tools you can purchase in advance to get ready), serving and appreciating them. In addition to oysters and knives, you can also buy Mr. McMurray’s book, “The Oyster Companion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Stephen Colbert’s late-night show will resume filming soon before a vaccinated live audience.
description: Starting June 14, about 400 people who present proof of vaccination against the coronavirus will be allowed to attend live tapings of the show, CBS said.
content: Stephen Colbert’s late-night talk show will return to filming in front of a studio audience on June 14, CBS said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Children With Covid Inflammatory Syndrome May Overcome Their Most Serious Symptoms
description: A small study found that six months after hospitalization, most children with MIS-C did not have debilitating health issues. But some had lingering muscle weakness and emotional difficulties.
content: Children who get sick from the rare but serious Covid-related inflammatory syndrome may surmount their most significant symptoms within six months, but they may still have muscle weakness and emotional difficulties at that time, a new small study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Max Mosley, Motor Racing Chief and Embattled Privacy Advocate, Dies at 81
description: The son of Nazi sympathizers sought to separate himself from his parents, but was bogged down by a secretly recorded sex video later in life.
content: Max Mosley, the former president of the International Automobile Federation, who forged a career that helped him emerge from the shadow of his notoriously fascist British parents but who became ensnared in legal battles later in life over a secretly recorded sex video, died on Monday. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Jade-Snow Joachim
title: Belarus, Schools, Israel: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Guth and Jennifer Kingsley
title: The Perilous Hunt for Coconut Crabs on a Remote Polynesian Island
description: On Makatea, an uplifted coral atoll marred by decades of mining, searching for crabs often requires gambling with the treacherous terrain.
content: We meet Adams Maihota outside his house in the dead of night. A crab hunter, he wears white plastic sandals, board shorts, a tank top and a cummerbund to hold lengths of twine. He picks a sprig of wild mint and tucks it behind his ear for good luck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Vivian Yee and Isabel Kershner
title: Blinken Will Seek to Bolster Cease-Fire Between Israel and Hamas
description: The secretary of state will also use his trip to the region this week to work on humanitarian aid for Gaza but has no plans to pursue full-fledged peace talks.
content: WASHINGTON — Wading into the intractable conflict between Israel and Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will travel to the Middle East this week to try to bolster a tenuous cease-fire — but he intends to steer well clear of longer-term peace talks that currently have almost zero chance of success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Apple’s Fortnite Trial Ends With Pointed Questions and a Toast to Popeyes
description: A decision over the antitrust suit filed by Epic Games, and the future of the $100 billion market for iPhone apps, is now in the hands of a federal judge.
content: Tim Cook took the stand for the first time as Apple’s chief executive. The billionaire creator of one of the world’s most popular video games walked a federal judge through a tour of the so-called metaverse. And lawyers in masks debated whether an anthropomorphic banana without pants was appropriate to show in federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: How Are You Right Now?
description: As this disrupted school year ends and pandemic restrictions ease, we wonder what you’re experiencing.
content: Our daily Student Opinion questions will soon end for the summer, but before we go, we wanted to check in with you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Strawberry Fields Crullers to Support Central Park
description: The sale of Daily Provisions’s latest doughnut, a limited-edition cruller, benefits the Central Park Conservancy.
content: As lush as the Great Lawn on a sunny day, the new Strawberry Fields cruller from Daily Provisions is a limited-edition confection designed to support the Central Park Conservancy. Crullers are a Daily Provisions specialty, and this one comes with matcha icing strewn with bits of tart dried strawberry to balance the sweetness. The crullers will be sold starting June 1 and through June 21, with $1 of the price donated to the Conservancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Scientists Partially Restored a Blind Man’s Sight With New Gene Therapy
description: Using a technique called optogenetics, researchers added light-sensitive proteins to the man’s retina, giving him a blurry view of objects.
content: A team of scientists announced Monday that they had partially restored the sight of a blind man by building light-catching proteins in one of his eyes. Their report, which appeared in the journal Nature Medicine, is the first published study to describe the successful use of this treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Naomi Lewkowicz and Sopan Deb
title: Rowdy, Rude and Really Loud: New York N.B.A. Fans Let Loose
description: The Knicks and Nets are in the playoffs together for the first time since 2013. Fans came out in droves to sports bars and arenas to celebrate.
content: We’re back, baby! The chants. The cursing at referees! The cursing at opposing players. The cursing just because you can! And that was just in living rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Why Arkansas Is a Test Case for a Post-Trump Republican Party
description: Sarah Huckabee Sanders seems likely to bring the Trump brand to Arkansas politics in a big way. But the state is a testing ground for different possible futures for the party.
content: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — For decades, Arkansas punched above its weight in politics and business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Paying the Price for Sun Damage
description: I’ve failed to practice what I preached about limiting sun exposure, but a new report has prompted me to reform.
content: Pick your favorite cliché: Do as I say, not as I do; an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure; better safe than sorry; forewarned is forearmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Start your week off with an old favorite (chipotle-rubbed steaks with cilantro-lime butter) or a brand-new recipe (tahini-Parmesan pasta salad).
content: Good morning. A million years ago I drove through Fall River, Mass., and down Route 88 toward Horseneck Beach in Westport on one of those warm, low-humidity, bluebird days that can make you fall in love with New England. I was bound for the home of Chris Schlesinger, one of my kitchen heroes, who was going to teach me his secrets of live-fire cooking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Just How Far Will Republican Attacks on Institutions Go?
description: For the G.O.P., overturning Roe v. Wade is a live possibility. Taking Jan. 6 seriously is not.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, as you know, I have a long history as a pro-choice conservative, going back to my days at The Wall Street Journal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Vaccine Class Gap
description: The biggest vaccination gap isn’t based on race or partisanship. It’s based on class.
content: It is common to hear about two different demographic groups that are hesitant to receive a Covid-19 vaccination: Republican voters and racial minorities, especially Black and Latino Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candida Moss
title: I’m a Vaccinated Transplant Recipient. I Don’t Have Antibodies. Now What?
description: As the vaccinated prepare to move on, the future for many of us is uncertain.
content: “When can we meet?” As more people are vaccinated, my inbox grows ever more hopeful. Emails from conference organizers, employers, friends, family and businesses promise that we will soon “get back to normal” and put the dark shadow of the pandemic behind us. Now that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has determined that masks are no longer necessary for the vaccinated, the spring has brought with it an optimistic news cycle that eagerly anticipates the post-Covid world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Adams Gets a Major Endorsement: 5 Takeaways From Mayor’s Race
description: Representative Adriano Espaillat, who had backed Scott Stringer, switched to supporting Eric Adams, while Andrew Yang had a rocky week on the campaign trail.
content: With just over four weeks left before the New York mayoral primary — and with in-person early voting set to begin on June 12 — the leading Democratic candidates are racing to distinguish themselves in an election that has so far remained relatively static, according to the limited polling available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Brigitte Bardot and the Beatles: What ‘Serpent’ Is Made of
description: The executive producer of the true crime series names the people, movies and music that inspired the sexy, stylish Netflix show.
content: Yes, Charles Sobhraj and Marie-Andrée Leclerc were dangerous psychopaths. In the 1970s, the suave Frenchman murdered a slew of backpacking hippies in Thailand and Nepal, while his Quebecois accomplice helped draw potential victims into their net.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Changing Tack, U.S. Sanctions Ethiopia Over Abuses in Tigray War
description: The measures signal a tougher American approach to a war in which Ethiopian forces are accused of atrocities. Ethiopia accused the U.S. of “meddling.”
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Growing American frustration over the war in the Tigray region of Ethiopia spilled over into an open confrontation on Monday when Ethiopian officials lashed out at Washington over new restrictions including aid cuts and a ban on some Ethiopians traveling to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel J. Emanuel and Govind Persad
title: This Is the Wrong Way to Distribute Badly Needed Vaccines
description: Countries should be getting vaccines based on their needs, not their population.
content: A global alliance to assure poor and moderate income countries “equitable access” to Covid vaccines is shortchanging nations in desperate need, while providing vaccines to others that have comparatively few cases or lack the ability to distribute them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Biden Doubles FEMA Program to Prepare for Extreme Weather
description: At the outset of hurricane and wildfire season, the Biden administration is doubling to $1 billion a fund that helps communities prepare for disasters.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration said it would spend $1 billion to help communities prepare for worsening disasters, the latest sign of the toll that climate change is already taking across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Passengers recall the fear that gripped the dissident journalist as their flight was diverted.
description: The tray tables were being raised and the seat backs returned to the upright position as passengers on Ryanair Flight 4978 prepared for the scheduled landing in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius. Then, suddenly, the plane made an abrupt U-turn.
content: The tray tables were being raised and the seat backs returned to the upright position as passengers on Ryanair Flight 4978 prepared for the scheduled landing in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius. Then, suddenly, the plane made an abrupt U-turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Snack Bar Gets Into Frozen Dessert
description: Kind Snacks has taken some of its popular snack bar flavors and reimagined them as a line of icy treats.
content: Kind bars have been around since 2004, and its line of products, primarily fruit and nut mixtures, has grown; the company has now introduced a frozen plant-based dessert you could happily mistake for high-end ice cream. Its main ingredient is not some alternate milk, but pear juice. The rich, complex flavors, mostly swirled abundantly with ingredients, are dark chocolate-almond-sea salt, dark chocolate-peanut butter, dark chocolate-cherry-cashew, coffee-hazelnut, caramel-almond-sea salt, strawberry and pistachio. They’re sold at supermarket chains including Kroger, Walmart and ShopRite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘Languages of Truth,’ Salman Rushdie Defends the Extraordinary
description: Rushdie’s new collection of essays includes an argument for brio-filled imaginative writing in an age of the humbler delights of autofiction.
content: Salman Rushdie has nothing to prove. Yet he finds himself, in his early 70s, deeply out of fashion. Too old to seize a moment, too active to be rediscovered, he’s been subject over the past two decades to some of the unkindest reviews ever delivered to a talent of his magnitude.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Rushdie
title: Ask Yourself Which Books You Truly Love
description: They will tell you a lot about who you are.
content: Before there were books, there were stories. At first the stories weren’t written down. Sometimes they were even sung. Children were born, and before they could speak, their parents sang them songs, a song about an egg that fell off a wall, perhaps, or about a boy and a girl who went up a hill and fell down it. As the children grew older, they asked for stories almost as often as they asked for food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: The E.U. moves quickly to isolate Belarus, denouncing its plane interception.
description: European leaders moved with uncharacteristic speed to step up the pressure on Belarus’s strongman leader.
content: The European Union on Monday called on all E.U.- based airlines to stop flying over Belarus and began the process of banning Belarusian airlines from flying over the bloc’s airspace or landing in its airports — effectively severing the country’s air connections to Western Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: ‘The Off-Season’ Is J. Cole’s Sixth Straight No. 1 Album
description: The rapper’s latest LP opens with the year’s biggest streaming total, and Olivia Rodrigo, projected to top the album chart next week, has the No. 1 song.
content: Two big new hits top the Billboard charts this week: J. Cole’s “The Off-Season” is the No. 1 album, with the year’s most robust streaming number so far, while Olivia Rodrigo’s “Good 4 U” is the top single.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: The Costly Pursuit of Self-Driving Cars Continues On. And On. And On.
description: Many in Silicon Valley promised that self-driving cars would be a common sight by 2021. Now the industry is resetting expectations and settling in for years of more work.
content: It was seven years ago when Waymo discovered that spring blossoms made its self-driving cars get twitchy on the brakes. So did soap bubbles. And road flares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: lithe
description: This word has appeared in 39 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Ex-Officer Is Sentenced to 6 Years in Beating of Unarmed Man
description: The former St. Paul, Minn., officer was convicted of using excessive force against a civilian who resembled the description of an armed suspect from a street fight.
content: A former police officer in Minnesota was sentenced to six years in prison on Friday for kicking a Black man who was on the ground being bitten by a police dog after officers mistook him for an armed suspect from a street fight in 2016, according to the authorities and court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Mitra Taj
title: Peru Massacre Revives Trauma of Maoist Violence Ahead of Polarized Vote
description: The killing, which comes weeks ahead of presidential elections, is one of the worst atrocities in Peru in decades.
content: Fourteen men, women and children died in a massacre in a remote coca-growing region of Peru, the Defense Ministry said, reviving memories of the country’s brutal left-wing insurgency just weeks ahead of presidential elections that are playing out along the conflict’s ideological fault lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: McGahn Is Likely to Testify Next Week on Trump’s Efforts to Obstruct Russia Inquiry
description: A delay is said to have stemmed from an initial threat by former President Donald J. Trump to intervene, but he apparently reversed course.
content: WASHINGTON — President Donald J. Trump’s former White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, has agreed to testify behind closed doors before the House Judiciary Committee sometime next week about Mr. Trump’s efforts to obstruct the Russia investigation, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: A ‘Hamilton’ Star Discovers Lunatic Comedy With ‘Girls5eva’
description: Renée Elise Goldsberry plays a delusional diva reuniting a girl group in a music biz satire executive produced by Tina Fey. It’s her midcareer moment.
content: It could have happened in her early 20s, fresh from college, with a face like a cherub and lungs like a hurricane, when she booked an understudy role in a Broadway-bound show that never arrived. Or 10 years later, when she moved to Los Angeles and sang with a jazz ensemble. Or five years after that, back in New York for a run on “One Life to Live,” or in the decade following, spent bounding between plays and short TV stints.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Banality of Democratic Collapse
description: Why are we on the edge? Blame the careerists, not the crazies.
content: America’s democratic experiment may well be nearing its end. That’s not hyperbole; it’s obvious to anyone following the political scene. Republicans might take power legitimately; they might win through pervasive voter suppression; G.O.P. legislators might simply refuse to certify Democratic electoral votes and declare Donald Trump or his political heir the winner. However it plays out, the G.O.P. will try to ensure a permanent lock on power and do all it can to suppress dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: New York City will not offer remote learning this fall.
content: New York City will no longer offer a remote schooling option in the fall, a major step toward fully reopening the nation’s largest school system and a crucial marker of the city’s recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: The Charms and Pitfalls of Dancing the Gods on Camera
description: This year’s iteration of the Indian dance festival, in two programs, is online; with Surupa Sen, what’s gained is emotional intimacy.
content: Since 2011, the World Music Institute’s Dancing the Gods festival has consistently delivered high-quality Indian dance to New York. Last year, like so much else, it was canceled. This year, like so much else, it’s virtual — which means that another stage experience is being mediated by cameras, with all the attendant possibilities and pitfalls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: ‘Charlie Bit My Finger’ Is Leaving YouTube After $760,999 NFT Sale
description: The original video of a baby biting his brother’s finger has drawn nearly 900 million views on the platform since 2007. But now one bidder owns it as a nonfungible token.
content: The original 2007 video “Charlie Bit My Finger,” a standard-bearer of viral internet fascination, has sold as a nonfungible token for $760,999, and the family who created it will take down the original from YouTube for good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: The U.S. is distributing stimulus aid to victims of domestic abuse, who faced even greater hardship in the pandemic.
description: The Department of Health and Human Services said it will award $200 million to help abuse victims get counseling, transitional housing and other help.
content: The Biden administration has begun to distribute hundreds of millions of dollars in funds to support victims of domestic abuse, a group that faced greater hardships and more danger while sheltering at home during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Scenes From America’s Reopening’
description: In this lesson, students will learn what reopening in America looks like — the joys, the relief, the uncertainties. Then they will document what reopening looks like in their communities.
content: Featured Article: “Scenes From America’s Reopening” by The New York Times
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: ‘I Owe Him My Life’: Chinese Runner Describes Mountain Rescue
description: After 21 runners died when high winds and freezing rain struck an ultramarathon race, one competitor said he  survived only because a shepherd carried his unconscious body to shelter.
content: The day began in jittery anticipation as 172 Lycra-clad runners jumped up and down at the starting line of the 62-mile mountain race in Gansu Province, China. Zhang Xiaotao noticed the wind as it blew the hats off some of his competitors. It was an early sign of the challenge ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Veggie Burger From the Sea
description: Akua’s plant-based burgers are made from cultivated kelp.
content: These burgers made in Portland, Maine, are plant-based but not trying to be meat. Kelp is the main ingredient, and they’re bolstered with mushrooms, pea protein, quinoa, black beans, chickpea flour and seasonings for a satisfying veggie burger. They’re best seared on a griddle, loaded with condiments and piled into a bun. Even if you knew how kelp tasted you probably couldn’t guess it from sampling these new iterations. Cook them while they’re still frozen; a leaf of wax paper separates them in the package and it can be removed with a quick warm water rinse. Or cook two together as a double burger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rejects Inmate’s Plea for Firing Squad
description: The inmate, Ernest Johnson, argued that Missouri’s planned use of pentobarbital to execute him would cause excruciating pain.
content: WASHINGTON — Over the dissents of its three liberal members, the Supreme Court on Monday refused to hear an appeal from a death row inmate in Missouri who said the way the state planned to execute him would cause him excruciating pain. The inmate, Ernest Johnson, had asked to instead be put to death by a firing squad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Is the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Down to 2 Candidates? Their Rivals Say No.
description: With less than a month before the June 22 primary, Democratic mayoral candidates are targeting the perceived front-runners, Eric Adams and Andrew Yang, in a bid to shift momentum.
content: First came the fevered pitch of the warm-up speeches and the catchy campaign jingle, in English and Spanish, which rang through the air at the park just south of City Hall. The New York City mayor’s race was approaching a pivotal moment, and Eric Adams, one of the top candidates, seemed prepared to seize it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Democrats, About to Miss a Police Reform Deadline, Hold Out Hope
description: The party will need G.O.P. buy-in to pass a bill — which could threaten activists’ priorities.
content: On Tuesday, Congress will arrive at — and blow right past — President Biden’s deadline for delivering a major police reform bill to his desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: A key impeachment witness against Trump sued Mike Pompeo over legal fees.
description: Gordon Sondland, a wealthy hotelier, says Mike Pompeo reneged on his promise to pay his legal fees after learning that his testimony hurt President Donald J. Trump.
content: A former top American diplomat who was a key witness against Donald J. Trump during his first impeachment sued former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and the federal government on Monday, demanding they pay his $1.8 million in legal fees from impeachment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: White House Seems to Affirm Biden’s Vow to Bar Seizures of Reporters’ Phone Data
description: But the Justice Department is not commenting on whether a seemingly off-the-cuff remark by President Biden is now a policy directive.
content: WASHINGTON — A White House spokeswoman appeared to confirm on Monday that the Biden administration would not permit federal prosecutors to seize reporters’ phone and email records in leak investigations, a potentially major change in law enforcement policy that President Biden promised in a seemingly off-the-cuff remark last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.6 Million Homes in California
description: A duplex in a landmark courtyard complex in West Hollywood, a 1922 cottage in Manhattan Beach and a Craftsman bungalow in Los Gatos.
content: The Andalusia is a courtyard complex built by the husband-and-wife architectural team Arthur and Nina Zwebell in 1926, and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 2003. One of the complex’s earliest residents was the silent film star Clara Bow; later in the 20th century, Marlon Brando occupied another unit. This duplex was designed by the Zwebells as their personal residence, and the seller recently undertook a restoration with the guidance of historic preservation experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Cable and Brake Failure Caused Cable Car Crash in Italy, Investigators Say
description: Charges including manslaughter and negligence are being considered following the accident in northern Italy that killed 14 people on Sunday.
content: STRESA, Italy — The crash of a cable car near picturesque Lake Maggiore in northern Italy, killing 14 people, occurred after a cable snapped and an emergency brake failed, investigators said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Six people on flight, including journalist, remained in Belarus.
description: At least six people who boarded the Ryanair flight in Athens were not on the plane when it finally arrived in Vilnius, Lithuania, the police commissioner of Lithuania said on Monday.
content: At least six people who boarded the Ryanair flight in Athens were not on the plane when it finally arrived in Vilnius, Lithuania, the police commissioner of Lithuania said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Belarus Is Isolated as Other Countries Move to Ban Flights
description: The extraordinary forced landing of a commercial flight with a Belarusian dissident aboard escalated into one of the biggest flare-ups in East-West tensions in recent years.
content: MOSCOW — The tray tables were being raised and the seat backs returned to their upright positions as passengers on Ryanair Flight 4978 prepared for the scheduled landing in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius. Then the plane made an abrupt U-turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Arlington and other national cemeteries relax restrictions before Memorial Day.
description: Limits will be lifted on funeral gatherings, graveside ceremonies will resume and vaccinated people will be free to visit without masks.
content: Just in time for Memorial Day weekend, Arlington National Cemetery and more than 150 national veterans’ cemeteries across the United States will drop many of the restrictions they imposed during the coronavirus pandemic and will allow vaccinated visitors to gather in large groups at graves without wearing masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: A Wrenching Knicks Loss, but an Electric Night at the Garden
description: N.B.A. playoff basketball returned to Manhattan as a cultural event with a loud, spirited crowd and a new archenemy, the Hawks’ Trae Young.
content: For 47 minutes 59.1 seconds, the fans at Madison Square Garden ranged from raucous to delirious, as the Knicks — their Knicks — were locked in a dogfight on Sunday night against the Atlanta Hawks in the New York team’s first N.B.A. playoff game since 2013.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: California’s Full-Capacity Reopening
description: Monday: Social distancing and other restrictions that have defined life in the pandemic will disappear on June 15, state health officials said.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Stop Kissing and Snuggling Chickens, C.D.C. Says After Salmonella Outbreak
description: More than 160 illnesses and dozens of hospitalizations have been reported across 43 states, officials said. “These are not house pets and a lot of people confuse that,” a poultry educator said.
content: A salmonella outbreak linked to backyard poultry has prompted U.S. health officials to issue a stern warning: Don’t kiss or snuggle your ducks and chickens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Taiwan, excluded from a world health forum, blames Chinese interference.
description: Taiwan’s government on Monday criticized the World Health Organization for capitulating to China after it failed to secure an invite to an annual health meeting convened by the international agency.
content: Taiwan’s government on Monday criticized the World Health Organization for capitulating to China after it failed to secure an invite to an annual health meeting convened by the international agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Restart Accelerates as ‘Hadestown’ Plans Its Return
description: This Tony Award-winning musical has chosen the earliest reopening date of any thus far: The curtain is to go up on Sept. 2.
content: “Hadestown,” the last show to win a Tony Award for best musical before the coronavirus pandemic shut down the theater industry, announced Monday that it is planning to resume performances on Sept. 2, nearly two weeks before any other Broadway shows have set their reopening date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery
title: Shirley Kost, Baseball’s ‘Cookie Lady,’ Dies at 82
description: Mrs. Kost would bestow cookies on her beloved Texas Rangers — players, coaches and employees — at home games. She died of complications of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Wong and Zack Wittman
title: Toronto’s Corrugated Fan Base Is on the Move Yet Again
description: The Blue Jays are still barred from playing in Canada, but as they decamp from Florida, their fans — in plastic cutout form — will make the trip to Buffalo.
content: Lauren Ash grew up in a baseball household in Belleville, Ontario, a two-hour drive from Toronto. When the Blue Jays won their first World Series, in 1992, a 9-year-old Ash became a lifelong fan. She moved to the city at 18, and sitting in the 500-level at SkyDome with friends became a ritual. Getting the chance to throw out the ceremonial first pitch at a game in 2014 was a career highlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Wong and Zack Wittman
title: Toronto’s Corrugated Fan Base Is on the Move Yet Again
description: The Blue Jays are still barred from playing in Canada, but as they decamp from Florida, their fans — in plastic cutout form — will make the trip to Buffalo.
content: Lauren Ash grew up in a baseball household in Belleville, Ontario, a two-hour drive from Toronto. When the Blue Jays won their first World Series, in 1992, a 9-year-old Ash became a lifelong fan. She moved to the city at 18, and sitting in the 500-level at SkyDome with friends became a ritual. Getting the chance to throw out the ceremonial first pitch at a game in 2014 was a career highlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: Delhi Considers Lifting Covid Limits, Despite Vaccine Shortage
description: Officials in the Indian capital have pledged to buy enough inoculations to avert another wave, but tight supplies and squabbling between central and local leaders make that a difficult prospect.
content: NEW DELHI — Delhi is considering relaxing its Covid-19 restrictions six weeks after a devastating coronavirus surge rocked the Indian capital, with a pledge to ramp up vaccinations to protect the city’s more than 20 million people from another wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Post-Embarrassment Media Campaign of Andrew Yang
description: He once called himself the opposite of Trump. But he is another test of the theory that in politics, there’s no such thing as bad publicity.
content: Years from now, when we look back on the history of pop-political interviewing, we may find it quaint that Sacha Baron Cohen had to disguise himself as Borat and Ali G in order to get public figures into uncomfortable situations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Cryptocurrency prices stabilize after another wild weekend.
description: Companies with Bitcoin on their balance sheets may be getting nervous. Three big corporate investors in Bitcoin are Tesla, MicroStrategy and Square.
content: Over the weekend, the price of Bitcoin briefly fell to around $31,000, more than 50 percent down from its high last month. It has recovered somewhat and is currently trading at around $37,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Graham-McLay
title: New Zealanders Are Flooding Home. Will the Old Problems Push Them Back Out?
description: More than 50,000 have escaped the pandemic by moving back, offering the country a rare chance to regain talented citizens. But they are confronting entrenched housing and employment challenges.
content: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Like many New Zealanders before her, Cat Moody chased the broader horizons of life abroad, unsure if she would ever return to a homeland she saw as remote and limiting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Under Pressure Over ‘Public Health’ Border Expulsions
description: The president faces a balancing act: how to keep his pledge of a more compassionate approach to migrants while managing a surge of people at the border amid a pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden is coming under increasing pressure to abandon a Trump-era immigration rule that has sealed off the United States to most migrants during the pandemic, with human rights officials and two of the administration’s own medical consultants saying the measure endangers vulnerable families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Hannon
title: How Food Trucks Endured and Succeeded During the Pandemic
description: Embracing technology, scaling down costs and general flexibility has helped them through a difficult time.
content: This article is part of Owning the Future, a series on how small businesses across the country have been affected by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Lordstown Motors halves the number of vehicles it will make in 2021.
description: The company says it is on track to begin production of its electric pickup trucks in late September.
content: Lordstown Motors, a start-up aiming to make electric pickup trucks, said on Monday that it would “at best” make just 50 percent of the vehicles it had previously hoped to this year, unless it is able to raise additional capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: E.U. leaders are meeting now to consider new sanctions against Belarus.
description: The chorus of condemnation and outrage from across the European Union swelled on Monday as leaders began discussing possible penalties they could direct at Belarus for its forcing down of a civilian passenger jet.
content: The chorus of condemnation and outrage from across the European Union swelled on Monday as leaders began discussing possible penalties they could direct at Belarus for its forcing down of a civilian passenger jet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John J. Lennon
title: How Vaccine Hesitancy Spread in My Prison
description: We can finally get the vaccine in prison. That doesn’t mean everyone will take it.
content: “Everyone’s being offered the vaccine. It’s Johnson & Johnson — one and done,” a bald administrator announced as he walked through the block. “It’s not mandatory! The officer is coming around with a list. Let him know — yes or no!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Stanley Reed
title: Airlines Start Skirting Belarus After It Forced Down a Plane
description: The European Union told airlines to avoid Belarusian airspace after the country forced a commercial flight to land in order to arrest a journalist.
content: The brazen decision by Belarus’s president this weekend to force a commercial flight to land in order to arrest a dissident journalist shows how abruptly aviation can become entangled in geopolitics, sometimes with dangerous potential consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Democrats, Once Outraged, Take a Quieter Approach to Migrant Children
description: House Democrats led angry efforts to denounce the Trump administration’s treatment of migrant children. With the issue bedeviling President Biden, they are voicing worries privately.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats, who led an angry charge against the Trump administration’s treatment of migrant children, have taken a much quieter tack since concerns began emerging about conditions at some of the emergency shelters set up by the Biden administration to deal with minors at the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Good Riddance, Leader McConnell
description: The judgment of history will be damning.
content: The judgment of history will be damning.

title: ‘High Maintenance’ and the New TV Fantasy of New York
description: As New York City is transformed by gentrification and inequality, comedies have begun depicting it as a place of magical connection.

title: Catastrophe’s Harvest
description: Climate change is propelling enormous human migrations as it transforms global agriculture and remakes the world order — and no country stands to gain more than Russia.

description: We created a 3D model of Greenwood, home of “Black Wall Street,” as it was before a white mob set it on fire 100 years ago.

description: “I’m so thankful that people still think I’m relevant, that they want to see what I do.”

title: ‘It’s Not Enough’: Living Through a Pandemic on $100 a Week
description: In one of the world’s most expensive cities, Isabel Galán has been surviving on odd jobs while juggling school and child care. Her life has come to revolve around how she spends the little cash she is able to earn: “I guard it as if it was gold.”
content: In one of the world’s most expensive cities, Isabel Galán has been surviving on odd jobs while juggling school and child care. Her life has come to revolve around how she spends the little cash she is able to earn: “I guard it as if it was gold.”
